title: Uruguay 3 - 1 Panama takeaways : Darwin Nunez stays on brand and Maxi Araujo scores a great goal

Marcelo Bielsaâ€™s Uruguay got off to a fast start at the Copa America, attacking Panama with nine shots in the first 20 minutes of their first group match in Miami. But even with the plentiful chances, they only managed a 1-0 lead until Liverpoolâ€™s Darwin Nunez sealed the victory in the 86th minute and Matias Vina made it 3-0 in added time. Panama got one back at the death to put the final score at 3-1.

Maxi Araujo scored the matchâ€™s first goal in spectacular fashion in the 16th minute. Nunez squandered several chances to extend the lead against an inferior opponent before he scored in the final five minutes. As dangerous as Uruguay looked early on, Panama gave them trouble at points in the second half, perhaps giving the U.S. something to think about as they prepare to face Panama on Thursday.
The Athleticâ€™s Thom Harris and Adam Crafton were at a less-than-full Hard Rock Stadium to share their takeaways from the match.
Darwin Nunez does Darwin Nunez things
A dramatic penalty shout, four shots and two big chances missed. A magnificent dummied assist, another glaring miss called offside, a new haircut, and a thumping goal. In no particular order.
Chaos follows Darwin Nunez wherever he goes, even across continents. His opening 90 minutes at this summerâ€™s Copa America, at the top of Marcelo Bielsaâ€™s expansive, full-throttle team, was as brilliantly unpredictable as quite literally anyone could have predicted.
â€œFor some players it was their first international game at this level,â€ Panama head coach Thomas Christiansen. â€œI think despite the errors we played really well. We were up against Darwin Nunez and we competed well, were really attentive to him.â€
Spectacle aside, the 25-year-oldâ€™s athleticism and relentlessness is a potential game-breaker. He already has nine goals in eight games under Bielsa, and while he should have added to that tally with a close-range side-footed shot in the first half, and a towering downward header in the second, his uncanny ability to attract opportunities funnels all of Uruguayâ€™s intense off-the-ball running towards the opposition goal.
Panama was unable to punish his wastefulness, and Nunez may not be so fortunate in games to come. But with sheer quantity, the quality invariably comes. â€”Thom Harris

Have we already seen the goal of the tournament?
Maximiliano Araujo wonâ€™t have been the first name to jump out to many from Uruguayâ€™s starting XI. Aged 24, playing his club football for Deportivo Toluca in Mexico, he has quickly become a mainstay under Bielsa, more for his versatility, energy and quick feet than moments of magic in the final third.
But as he received the ball from his fullback Matias Vina, dragging the ball under his control in one, swift spin, everything seemed to open up.
The move was typical of Uruguayâ€™s attacking play; darting movement off the ball, a crisp first-time pass and an instinctive dummy to find the yard of space. Taking an extra touch to steady himself, he looked up, picked his spot, before whipping a wicked left-footed shot over the outstretched arm of Orlando Mosquera and into the far corner.
Uruguay will score plenty of goals this tournament, but their first will be hard to top. â€”Harris

Should this game have been held at a smaller venue?
Walking up to the 65,000-seat Hard Rock Stadium, the home of the NFLâ€™s Miami Dolphins and the venue for this summerâ€™s Copa America final, it was difficult not to be swept away by the charm and enthusiasm of the Uruguayan and Panamanian supporters who had taken over the parking lots outside the stadium.
The scene was a blur of light blue Uruguay shirts and deep red Panama, with the Uruguayans setting up portable barbecues and breaking into song. Inside the stadium, however, there were swathes of empty seats dotted around the lower tiers, but particularly visible in the upper tiers.
There is plenty to criticise about CONMEBOLâ€™s approach to marketing and pricing this competition in the U.S. this summer but the issue here appeared to lie in the fact it always seemed ambitious, to say the least, to hold a match between Uruguay (population 3.4m) and Panama (4.4m) in such a vast stadium. The supporters did not stop singing, yet in a venue this size, it always looked a little hollow, and perhaps it would have been smarter to hold the event in a smaller MLS stadium, which really would have got the place rocking and packed out. In the end, the attendance came in at 33,425.
There may be a lesson here, also, for FIFA, who will want to avoid embarrassment at some of the games involving less famous teams at next yearâ€™s Club World Cup, while the U.S.-Mexico bid for the Womenâ€™s World Cup in 2031, which may be the first womenâ€™s tournament to be expanded to 48 teams â€” and using NFL-sized stadiums â€” yet it may be more prudent and a better product to use a mix of MLS and NFL stadia. â€”Adam Crafton

What did the managers say?
Uruguay head coach Marcelo Bielsa: â€œThe first half was a performance where we showed our superiority and we could have scored more goals than we did. The second half, there were 15-20 minutes or so where we didnâ€™t play so well; they dominated these phases of play and created some chances and there was only a goal in it. It could have become complicated for us. After twenty minutes of the second half, we were dominating again and creating chances and the result seemed to represent what happened on the field.â€
Panama head coach Thomas Christiansen: â€œWe had too much respect for Uruguay in first half. We made many mistakes, too many loose passes, short passes we donâ€™t normally miss. This generated dangerous chances for Uruguay. We had too much respect â€” we have to have respect but not fear. When we demonstrated fear, we made mistakes.â€
